According to various studies and data, Native Hawaiians have higher rates of recidivism compared to other racial groups. A 2017 study published in the Journal of Offender Counseling and Rehabilitation found that Native Hawaiians had a higher rate of recidivism within three years of release compared to African Americans, Hispanics, and whites. Another study published in 2019 in the Journal of Criminal Justice found that Native Hawaiians were more likely to reoffend within the first year of release compared to other racial groups.

There are several reasons why Native Hawaiians may be more likely to reoffend. One reason is that they often face significant barriers to employment and housing upon release, which can make it difficult for them to establish stable lives and avoid returning to criminal behavior. Additionally, Native Hawaiians may experience discrimination and bias in the criminal justice system, which can lead to higher rates of recidivism.

Overall, while it is important to recognize that each individual has their own unique circumstances and experiences, the data suggests that Native Hawaiians are more likely to reoffend compared to other racial groups.
